awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Head Start on Engineering: Developing a Learning Community to Study and Support Family-level Interest in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
There are several critical reasons to understand and support interest development in early childhood: (a) as a primary motivator of engagement and learning; (b) interest development in preschool predicts important learning outcomes and behaviors in early elementary school; and (c) early childhood interests motivate ongoing interest development. Thus, there is growing recognition that interest is not just important but fundamental to education and learning. Head Start on Engineering (HSE) is a multi-component, bilingual (Spanish/English), family-focused program designed to (1) foster long-term interest in the engineering design process for families with preschool children from low-income backgrounds and (2) support family development and kindergarten readiness goals. The HSE program, co-developed with the Head Start community, provides families with developmentally appropriate, story-based engineering design challenges for the home and then connects these to a system of strategically aligned Informal STEM Education (ISE) experiences and resources. This current project, HSE Systems, builds on a previous HSE Pathways project which (a) established that participating families develop persistent engineering-related interests; (b) highlighted the value that the Head Start community has for the program and partnership; and (c) generated a novel, systems perspective on early childhood interest development. The aim of HSE Systems is to develop and test a model of early childhood STEM engagement and advance knowledge of how the family as a system develops interest in STEM from preschool into kindergarten.

Through the Design Based Implementation Research (DBIR) process, the team will iteratively refine and improve the HSE program and theory of change using ongoing feedback and data from staff, families, and partners. It is also designed to explore program impacts on family interest development over a longer period, as children enter kindergarten. The DBIR work will focus primarily on the program model questions, while the case study research will focus on the family interest questions, with both strands informing each other. The initial work is organized around a series of feedback and design-testing cycles to gather input from families and other stakeholders, update the program components and activities in collaboration with families and staff, and prepare for full implementation. During the next phase, the team will implement the full program model with six Head Start classrooms and track family experiences and interest development into kindergarten. During final implementation phase, the team will finish data collection, conduct retrospective analysis with all the data, and update the program model and theory of change.

This project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. It will directly address the AISL program goals by broadening access to early childhood informal STEM education for low-income communities, with a focus on Spanish-speaking families, and building long-term skills and learning dispositions to support STEM learning inside and outside of school. Beyond the topic of engineering, HSE supports Head Start school readiness and child and family development goals, which are the foundation of lifelong success.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

inst.inst_name: Oregon Museum of Science and Industry
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: OREGON MUSEUM OF SCIENCE AND INDUSTRY

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Mt. Hood Community College Head Start

por.por_cntn:
Head Start on Engineering (HSE) is a multi-component, bilingual (Spanish/English), family-focused program designed to foster long-term interest in the engineering design process for families with preschool children from low-income backgrounds and support Head Start child and family development goals. Ongoing partnership is essential to the development, delivery, and research elements of the program. The initiative is led by TERC in partnership with Mt. Hood Community College (MHCC) Head Start, Oregon Museum of Science and Industry (OMSI), and University of Notre Dame. 

 

Within the five years of funding covered in this report, the team worked with Head Start families and staff to co-develop and refine engineering activities, and to develop and iterate engineering-focused meeting agendas tailored for parents, families, and Head Start staff. We also worked to disseminate project learnings about engineering with young children through academic articles, professional conferences, and other gatherings. Over the years we involved over 50 families in data collection activities, and upwards of 400 families in celebration activities, such as a night at OMSI. Over 150 Head Start Staff were included in professional training events on engineering activities and approaches.

 

Over the 5 years of funding covered in this report, the HSE project team flexibly adapted program plans and research methods to support the Head Start community during the onset and ongoing impacts of the COVID pandemic. As a part of this, the team began in year one to articulate two equity principles: collaborating as equal partners and informing an equitable vision of engineering education. These principles informed the approaches of the project team, including the ways in which the team developed and updated family engineering activities and in how the team established meeting formats to provide safe opportunities for families to attend and share their experiences in the language(s) most comfortable for them. This equity approach has been supported through an “equity coach” role on the team, which serves as a guide and resource to refine the team’s approaches and practice. 

 

Engineering activities were refined over the years with an increasing understanding of and focus on supporting caregivers’ existing goals. Some of the common goals shared by families were: including older and younger siblings and diverse family structures in activity design, emphasizing the connections between engineering activities and everyday problem-solving practices, trying new things, spending time together as a family, and building skills and knowledge. Head Start staff shared goals of wanting the program to support the work already ongoing in the classroom and in home visits.  As we learned more about these goals, we explicitly included discussion of them in our meetings and conversations, letting families and staff know that their input had a direct and ongoing impact on the program design. Similarly, meeting and communication formats were refined through an increased focus on relationship-building which supported family and Head Start staff engagement and personal storytelling. We explored different formats and strategies with staff, parents, and families, streamlined the program activities to lessen the burden of participation, and included Arabic language accessibility within the program materials and facilitation. 

 

As we centered the voices, experiences, and goals of families and Head Start staff in the program, the project team refined our asset-based visions of what engineering looks like within the diverse caregiving systems surrounding young children. This included recognizing the many ways in which families creatively adapted their participation in the program around ongoing challenges, and uplifting everyday problem solving within families and classrooms as sophisticated engineering practices.


 

 


Last Modified: 11/25/2024
Modified by: Annie H Douglass
